replies.author: @aikaterineillt9876
replies.text: That's what I have been saying for years, I am glad the complexities of this topic are being acknowledged. I have felt alone in my efforts, like a cat forever in the center of a pack of dogs, fighting the world..just to regard the cold, harsh truth. Exhausting myself and being picked to the bone before I can even get to the point of discussing possible solutions.  We need to talk about "envy" too (as we have with "insecurity") and how that word should not be thrown around as an assault on someone's character either. Envy (or jealousy for those who use the terms interchangeably) is the inevitable, justified result of gross unfairness and insurmountable injustices, it is the very thing that pushes us toward closing the gaps..it is what fuels us to improve our quality of life, it is what underpins rebellion and pleas for equality. Same thing with "comparison", they tell us "comparison is the thief of joy" and don't we know it, but everyone compares themselves to others for various reasons (including attractive people who compare themselves to us in order to feel special and superior, at our expense), none of us live in a vacuum, most things are what they are due to how they relate to something or someone else. You cannot go through life without recognizing this and being forced to adhere to it, especially if you're at the bottom of the totem pole...you are not given any other options, beyond deluding yourself into oblivion. And let's be honest..attractive people would not have it any other way. They don't want the status quo to change, they want us to be envious, they NEED us to be..and they need us to exist as something "less than" so that they can be seen as "more than", in the most superficial, unearned way imaginable- but which still holds so much significance in society and in our sense of identity.

replies.author: @gogochow7525
replies.text:
‚Äã@deforestshell3037  The way you feel about yourself is how people will perceive you.

Beauty is a self-concept. 

This is why charismatic individuals who don't conform with beauty standards are perceived as magnetic and intriguing. 
This is also why funny guys can attract conventionally beautiful women. I wish people could understand that your beauty is like a painting. 

It is unique to you by its composition, colors, imperfections, and meaning. 
As you may already, art appreciation is highly  subjective. 

You will never conform to any beauty standard because you are the standard and the standard is you.

Present your self-concept to the world and let the rest do its job.

replies.author: @deforestshell3037
replies.text: ‚Äã@gogochow7525 no, it's not.It's very much based on how people treat you and everybody knows by the time you hit puberty. Most kids don't even care about this stuff until we all hit puberty , and all those hormones start kicking in , then you really see how you are treated by society

replies.author: @gogochow7525
replies.text:
‚Äã@deforestshell3037 Having confidence in yourself is something that you should be taught and helped build as you navigate this world. I am aware thant not everyone has access to someone who can help navigate phases of change in life but the most important thing is to ultimately realize that your self-concept is what matters. When you are young, your self-concept is not always as developed as when you are older and that's okay.  

We all know that the younger crowd is highly susceptible to what society dictates and parrots any behavior they are exposed to including the adaptation and acceptance of unrealistic and unattainable societal beauty standards, especially when they are experiencing this identity crisis. 

Life is a journey and feeling comfortable in your own skin as well as building up your confidence can take time.

Good luck on your journey!

@lis@lisajordan8098now how it feels. You aren‚Äôt alone. Hell, speaking of which, I‚Äôve been working really hard on my BDD (body dysmorphia disorder),
which developed from a ton of people around who treated me as lesser than due to my looks.

But I have hope I‚Äôll heal in full. I used to refuse being in photos, but no longer do. I even take the occasional selfie. I wear and buy clothes I genuinely love now instead of ones I have no care for due to ‚ÄúI‚Äôll look like a pig no matter what I wear.‚Äù 

I‚Äôm getting there. Still struggle eating in front of people, still observe and prod at every flaw in the mirror and still believe there‚Äôs ‚Äúno way anyone can find me physically attractive.‚Äù Even when hit on, I always take it as ‚Äúthey just see me as an easy lay who oughta feel lucky.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a long and incredibly tough progress. We got this, everyone. We‚Äôll heal, despite the harsh standards and treatments.

‚Äã@cresentj 

This is my piece. It may help your or someone else out there.

You need to free yourself from societal expectations. Look at public figures in this world. Do they all adhere to standards of beauty? Now ask yourself why should you, if not all of them do. This is proof that beauty is multifaceted.

Beauty is subjective and you can decide where yours stems from. This is where the real magic happens.

I truly hope you get there because we all ask ourselves those questions in life including myself.

Even if you become attractive, people will still treat you badly. Women will treat you as if you don't matter and you have no real problems because "at least you are pretty" and most guys you run into are just trying to F you and some don't care how they do it. It‚Äôs nice to put this topic on the table, that being said, an injustice is making somebody think they ARE ugly instead of that they LOOK ugly. Otherwise you are conditioning someone to understand ugliness as his literal essence, when it‚Äôs just a stage. If you gain weight don‚Äôt wear makeup and leave your hair as is, chances are people will see you as ugly. If you have a bad haircut and no eyebrows, people will likely see you as ugly. 
A girl in my school had insane facial structure, but was chubby and had short hair and no eyebrows, she let her hair grow and grew back her eyebrows and went to being the literal most beautiful girl in class. Most cases, you are not ugly, you LOOK ugly. It‚Äôs also interesting how it changes, I ahowed this video to one of my friends and he said the host is not one to talk about pretty privilege, and I can assure you the group chat would agree, nevertheless, I wouldn‚Äôt call you ugly, I‚Äôd say you LOOK ugly under those standards.

I wasn't told I was attractive until I was about 18. My life has changed dramatically in that time, from being a laughing stock in school, to being ignored by everyone ever in college, to making friends in the middle of the street, to becoming severely disabled and having all of those friends leave, and now finally being happy enough with my body (thank you HRT) that I find myself attractive regardless of other people's opinion. I still assume I'm ugly on instinct though, hiding from cameras, never showing my teeth, assuming I'm creeping out anyone I'm talking to, etc.
When you have it drilled into you for so long that you're ugly and that's a bad thing, you believe it even when you know it's not true

replies.author: @ChanteSWilliams
replies.text:
A lot of it depends on the group of people you are around, though.

I grew up in a cult. That boys in the cult knew me my entire life, and we're closer to me than most kids are to other children they aren't blood related to. So, these boys saw me more like a sister. They would tease me a lot. They didn't flirt with me when we were adolescents. They always talked about other girls being pretty, and acted like I was chopped liver.

When I was older, and I wasn't in the cult anymore, I made friends with many gorgeous young women. Every time we went out, older people and children would tell them how pretty they were, but I never got compliments. Men would come up and flirt with them, ask for their number, ask them out, pay for their meals, etc.. But, they completely ignored me, as though I was completely invisible.

But, I moved away. I didn't make friends automatically, because my work schedule made it difficult to develop many friendships. So, when I would go shopping, go out to eat, go to festivals, or go to movies, etc., I would go alone. I would often get compliments on my looks, get hit on by men, and even had multiple photographers stop me and ask me to model for them. I was shocked. I did low level modeling. I didn't make tons of money. I wasn't famous, of course. But, I would make $400-$1,500 a month, depending on the month. 

The thing is, I looked exactly the same when I was invisible as I did when I was being perceived as pretty.

I feel you. 
For me it was the looks + undiagnosed autism combo. 

Interesting enough, when you're afab and autistic (or having some kind of other developmental disability), being pretty is kind of what determines whether you're seen as 'outcast weird' or 'quirky weird'. I've heard from other afab folk that they got treated better when performing hyperfemininity, their avoiding eye contact was seen as being 'endearingly shy' when fem but was seen as rude and disrespectful when they looked 'average'. 
Might also have to do with some weird manic pixie dream girl thing, since how often do you see those be portrayed as not conventionally attractive. 

Of course there's other factors, but I feel like when you're specifically in that 'not autistic enough to be seen as disabled' but 'not allistic enough to be seen as 'normal' your looks can be a big contributing factor.

replies.author: @AntoineLefort83
replies.text: Big of you to say, but yeah absolutely. I think it's human nature to recoil and feel negative emotions upon seeing something we find aesthetically unpleasant. We are visual animals, and our empathy is actually connected to our eyes. This is precisely why babies, of all animals whose parents care for them, are "cute". It's a strategy to play on the emotions of their parents and trigger their empathy. Empathy comes from first saying "I like the look of that". This is why it's actually SO extremely dark and hazardous to have a society dictating what is beautiful, and painting certain people as ugly and less. To some extent ugly is ugly, and those uglies are doomed, and even I am like "ew! F-- you!" when I see these people. But to add people to the roster of "ugly" based purely on things like race or other trivial things, when they're actually attractive, is messed up.  We should be trying to reduce the window of ugliness, to maximise empathy, not reducing empathy by expanding the window of ugliness. You can think of a case like George Floyd, the diminished empathy for him despite the clear video of him being brutally murdered, the reaching for excuses, it was all because those people were trained by society to find his exaggerated negro features ugly. Scary. People can literally watch you be murdered and like it, because they find you ugly, because society drilled into them that you are.

replies.author: @aribahossain6234
replies.text: @AntoineLefort83  that‚Äôs an interesting perspective. Will it be too much for me to hope that someday we can disconnect our empathy from visuals and be able to extend that empathy to those our subconscious find visually unappealing. If we can be be intentional and try, maybe we can see their suffering first before their aesthetics in our eyes

replies.author: @AntoineLefort83
replies.text: @aribahossain6234 I'm sure some manage to train themselves to do that already, or are just so overflowing with empathy they can find it for all living things, but I do believe there's a default setting built into people, and maybe primates and mammals even, where the visual aesthetic holds an inordinate amount of weight in determining the empathy that is conjured. Unfortunately. I've experienced it first hand. I was a very attractive teenager, just accidentally, a tanned skateboarder boy with 6 pack abs and the little obliques cutting in at the side of the abs and a cherubic face and girls asking to touch my body, and yeah, I took for granted this strange empathy I seemed to draw from every man woman and child, the elderly, my aunties, just regular straight guys ... everyone. And then I got to experience that wither away so sharply, starting in my 20s and just falling off a cliff since. My disposition actually got much sweeter and more humble and kind in correlation with this physical visual decline, and I retained or improved my wit and sense of humour or whatever might have made me friends in the first place, but increasingly people just became cold and didn't care if I lived or died, and I could so distinctly feel it coming at me from every single angle after having experienced being one of the beautiful people. Combine this with my extensive David Attenborough education, and its just so clear to me the animal behaviours at play. I can also see this phenomenon reflected with the classic "Karen". Every Karen was once a beautiful young girl, everyone treating her like gold, and then suddenly they started ... not. And the Karen starts losing her mind as the world stops being nice to her. She needs to speak to the manager because she needs to get the "justice" of the pretty privilege she used to receive. I really feel for them, I'm a male karen who is just sad instead of angry. I notice the Karens are often even the same complexion as me... the kind that turns sour in the sun, and balloons out shapeless in the body in all the wrong places. A lineage that doesn't age well, after reaching such dizzying heights in our teenage years... the world turns SO cold. The black karen is rare, for two reasons- were never treated that well in the first place, and also never cracked so badly.

replies.author: @karaleigh_eva
replies.text:
Empathy is a natural emotion. But it‚Äôs also an emotional skill that can be built and a choice that can be made. 

Let‚Äôs look at animals for example. 
It is incredibly easy to empathize with cats, puppies, baby deer ‚Äî that ‚Äúcuteness‚Äù element makes it just a natural instinct to empathize with them and feel an almost parental need to want them to be cared for. 

But ugly creatures ‚Äî the bugs, the rats, the rodents, the hogs ‚Äî people have to make the decision to be empathetic and treat them compassionately. They have to have the knowledge and emotional skills to unpack their innate negative feelings and instead lead with empathy. 

The same applies to our human peers. We have to unlearn the ways we‚Äôve been led to innately feel toward criminals and homeless, untrain the way we might even instinctually feel toward the disabled and the sickly ‚Äî and build our empathy skills to care for all of our neighbors

replies.author: @AntoineLefort83
replies.text: ‚Äã@Eeokyeah so it is just "what you find beautiful", rather than "what is technically beautiful". That's why different people have more or less empathy for different things. The cliche "so ugly it's cute bulldog" I'm sure generates empathy from tonnes of people. Me included. A lot of people, not me included, often find very elderly people "cute" and have elevated empathy for them. I lean more towards finding them gross, and I have diminished empathy for them. I'm also compelled to "find logic" for why their lives don't matter as much. I know this is technically immoral, but this is the inclination in me I have no real control over. It's a visceral feeling, and then a tendency I notice in hindsight. But the good thing about having this darkness and recognising it, is I can then easily see it and recognise it in other people. So for example I can see this phenomenon in a lot of racist people. It's literally just firstly a visceral reaction to finding the way they look bad, and from there they kind of don't care if (for example) a police officer shoots them, and then they will rationalise why the shooting is justified and see all angles of excuses for the officer but all stemming from finding the victim visually repellent and therefore having diminished empathy. I'm someone who, for some reason, LIKES the way black people look. The women I find attractive, the men I think "look cool", so I'm upset when I see them suffer. This is generally how empathy works and once you understand it you'll see it everywhere and notice how consistent it is.

replies.author: @Kebbythetraveler
replies.text: Looking back I definitely felt a version of this growing up as the beauty standard changed to center me in my late teens and early 20s. I am pasty white with dark hair. I'm tall with a fat ass and big pouty lips. Growing up in the South I watched other white and Latina girls with my color get highlights or go blonde to better fit the beauty standard, not to mention tanning. I saw my hair color as something I was expected to but didn't want to fix (to this day I've never dyed it). It was only when someone asked me if I dyed it when I was 17 that it occurred to me people might not only keep it but choose it on purpose. I'm pretty but have an intense resting bitch face that even adults in my life commented on growing up. Feeling the tide in beauty shift to IG baddies definitely made me understand that whatever was in societally was a trend. It's interesting looking at fashion throughout the 19th and 20th centuries and seeing that cycle in action. I just happened to be on trend. I also did nothing to look like this and understand it's pure luck. I can't give someone a doctor rec or an exercise regimen, I just look like this. No Protestant Work Ethic Here ¬Ø‚Å†\‚Å†_‚Å†(‚Å†„ÉÑ‚Å†)‚Å†_‚Å†/‚Å†¬Ø

author: @tariahwebber671
text: As an autistic black woman I learned early on that if I played into the look ideals of the community I was in I would gain more access. This access was so powerful and I realized that I could be weird or smart as long as I was pretty. Let‚Äôs just say growing up in white spaces meant that I always had to be ten steps ahead so I faced less discrimination. A fight that a lot of pretty white people will never fully grasp.

replies.author: @tweakr4377
replies.text: @tariahwebber671 I‚Äôm white passing and autistic and I completely agree with this. Even as someone who was AMAB, and therefore experienced what you are talking about to a lesser degree, I still deeply felt that my attractiveness was a massive determining factor in how I was treated, and it really left an impression on me. When I got more attractive during puberty, I was seen as less nerdy and weird, and more charming and intelligent, and had a much easier time making friends and having romantic relationships. Due to my autism, I have a really difficult time ascertaining how attractive I am, and I am constantly in fear of being unattractive, or having always been unattractive because I know first hand how impactful it is when it comes to acceptance.

replies.author: @Muchomorek-vp9nw
replies.text:
‚Äã@JadeReloaded it's great you don't want to pass down the toxic behaviour of your family to your daughter. I know you are doing your best. Something I would suggest you to think about is that children learn from observation. So if you still hate looking in the mirror I'm worried your daughter may be affected by that. It's nothing wrong in not doing everything perfect. We are all just humans. Maybe consider visiting specialists in that topic, I would do some meditation while watching my mirror reflection and try staring in my own eyes. Eyes are usually the part of the body people like about themselves so it's good start point. Also there is something spiritual in them for me, I know its just my perspective but I think most people get what I'm talking about, even in society and culture somehow, even in the late capitalism, we value it and see it as something personal. 
What is more about looking in the mirror directly into your eyes there are studies that shows that if you do it long enough you start to have hallucinations. The shapes of your face start to change. For me it's the realisation point that everything is just an illusion. Helps me to look at everything with much more distance.

author: @Lockw1e
text:
As an "ugly" person, I found out that conventionally attractive people get really defensive when you point out that they're experiencing everything differently, because they often have  never faced the fact that most people like them mainly for their looks. It's a painful realisation to them. So most of them prefer to deny that anyone is ugly or that they are beautiful or that it gives them any sort of advantage.

When I realised that, I also realised it must kinda suck to be liked by superficial people. So I felt a little bit less bad about being ugly.

replies.author: @bonnieparker1725
replies.text:
I think maybe this phrasing is slightly misleading. I think I get where you're coming from in that, absolutely, our interactions with strangers are 200% coloured by how attractive they perceive us as. 

But saying that 'most people like them mainly' for their looks makes it sound as though even friendships they might have are largely based on physical attractiveness, and this isn't smth I've found to be true. There certainly are 'friends' who re mainly drawn to someone for their looks or popularity, but there are also social connections that extend beyond that. When I was at my most conventionally unattractive I might not have gotten any attention from the opposite sex but I still had amazing friends, several of whom were also not conventionally attractive. It's possible I misunderstood what you meant though and that you were mostly referring to strangers/general preferential treatment?

replies.author: @Lockw1e
replies.text: ‚Äã@bonnieparker1725 I think you did misunderstand a little bit, I think we get better friends when we are "uglier". Some people are genuine, but it's hard for conventionally attractive people to tell the difference and filter out superficial people. Meanwhile being "ugly" is a natural filter, and we're more likely to have deep friendships (although we might have less friends overall).

replies.author: @bonnieparker1725
replies.text:
‚Å†@Lockw1eAh, if that's what you meant I still kinda disagree because I feel like it's too much of an absolutist statement. I definitely didn't have an easier time making friends once I became more conventionally attractive. And I also disagree that conventionally attractive people, as a rule, are less likely to have deeper connections. They are also still complex human beings with their own personalities and families and experiences that will shape how they interact with others.

As I said in my first comment, definitely agree that how stranger treat you or how people interact with you dating wise will depend greatly on your looks, and yes, there is absolutely preferential treatment. I just disagree on the friends bit bc I think that's too generalised of a statement.

replies.author: @Lockw1e
replies.text: ‚Äã@bonnieparker1725nothing absolutist about anything I said. "More likely" doesn't mean always/for sure/in every case.

replies.author: @PandorasExecutioner
replies.text: You're right it does suck to be liked by superficial people. I've been frumpy and I've been pretty, and I can definitely tell when people are treating me with genuine respect or not. Like when I show up frumpy, people are rude but I also have deep friendships based on personality. And when I've appeared more pretty, I still have deep friendships, but strangers will coddle me and I absolutely despise it because it's disrespectful in a different way. You get more favor as a pretty person, which is safer, but it's a different kind of disrespect because my authority and intelligence wasn't respected. People came to my defense, which is nice, but would also undermine me. I was a Doll to protect instead of an equal person. So I think women face the intersectional challenge of facing misogyny as Ugly vs facing misogyny with Pretty Privilege. I used to struggle with recognizing when people were gendering me, and recognizing when I'm being treated different in a Structural way has absolutely helped me steer clear. this video is definitely reminding me to uplift my opposites if I am currently occupying privilege. Pretty people definitely have more freedom to be weird and perceived as "quirky."

author: @sheilasackett6781
text:
When I was in the fourth grade or thereabouts, a popular girl called me over to her lunch table, and when I went over, she looked me up and down and said, ‚Äúyou are so ugly‚Äù. 
I‚Äôve never forgotten it. I‚Äôm 63 now. I am married over 37 years to a wonderful man, I have two amazing daughters, a career to be proud of. I hear that voice from the fourth grade every day. Every. Single. Day.
People, be kinder to one another.

replies.author: @aribahossain6234
replies.text:
I‚Äôm sorry this happened to you. She‚Äôs the true ugly one for doing that, and with time people will see that. 
We may not be able to stop the voices, but we can try and control how we react to them 
Sending a hug ‚ù§

replies.author: @sheilasackett6781

replies.author: @natashalena7571
replies.text:
@sheilasackett6781  I was replying to the ur first response, where you admitted that "it was you"...(but you must have deleted that response), "indecisive responses", yet another sign of weakness...*sigh*. I actually typed up a response to that one comment you deleted & since I am not indecisive, I will proceed with typing that very response for you regardless... Look, words only have the power of affecting you, if you believe them & if you allow them to. I'm just some stranger on the internet, but in this case I'm being honest with you... Never let anyone know ur weakness's, surround yourself with ppl that are better than you & manifest surpassing them, (And you will)...

That girl from grade-school, tell urself she was an unhappy little girl who was simply jealous of you...(her words are not "Divine Scripture", are they?). Would you ever seek out a 4th grader for abject truth? She may very well have been an inadequate little brat, that was trying to get under ur skin, in order to compensate for her inadequacy... But she cannot get under ur skin, unless you allow her, ( so don't allow her to). In the end, all these yrs later, she probably doesn't even remember the exchange she had with you & yet you've allowed her to live rent free in ur brain for 50-plus yrs, to the point where her words still very much affect you. So yes, my response to ur initial reply which you deleted still stands..."Yes, it is YOU".

author: @wwatse
text:
I‚Äôve always said the ‚Äú just be confident ‚Äú is probably the worst advice you could give to someone. Insecurity is a response to negative reinforcement over a lifetime. You can‚Äôt ‚Äú just be confident ‚Äú if you have nothing to be confident about.

edit: I‚Äôm talking specifically about when people feel insecure in their looks or feel ugly because they‚Äôve been told over many years that they are ugly or been made fun of for their looks.

I‚Äôm not saying you can‚Äôt have confidence in other parts of your life, because that‚Äôs what the video is basically about.

You can have confidence in your abilities, that has nothing to do with your looks.

Felt like I had to clarify cause a lot of comments think I‚Äôm saying you can‚Äôt be confident at all in all matters if you are ugly, it‚Äôs totally my fault for not wording the comment well, my bad üôè.

replies.author: @Aster_Risk

replies.author: @digestmymind
replies.text: Exactly. And it has to be understood that confidence builds AFTER doing something. That's why "do it scared" or "do it anxious" are much more empowering. Yes, there are things that are scary. You should do them anyways if it's what you truly desire. And afterwards, that builds your confidence. The threshold to do that activity is much lower.

replies.author: @wwatse
replies.text:
@digestmymind I am talking specifically about looks, you know, like when people say ‚Äú you are not ugly, you just have to be more confident ‚Äú.
I really don‚Äôt know what you can do to improve your confidence in such cases when all other parts of you life like your inability to get a partner or being made fun of for looking ugly or being insulted with your looks when you are involved in a conflict keep reinforcing to you that you are ugly.
All these things build your insecurity over time and I really don‚Äôt know what you can do about that than just be insecure about your looks.

I feel like I didn‚Äôt make it clear enough that I was talking specifically about looks.

replies.author: @wwatse
@digestmymind
replies.text: ‚Äã@wwatse I'm making a specific attack on the understanding of how confidence is built in the first place, to be clear.  The reason I mention "doing" is because in practice ‚Äúconfidence in your looks‚Äù usually only comes up in situations where looks are directly tied to outcomes (dating, being teased, social standing, etc.). It‚Äôs not like someone randomly says ‚Äúbe confident in your looks‚Äù when nothing is at stake. Someone can't "just be confident" in their looks, because that confidence is built after positive reinforcement; it's why desirable people are confident in their looks despite not doing much else. The problem for people who are seen as ugly is that society gives them way fewer chances to get that feedback in the first place, which makes the cycle way harsher.

replies.author: @notimportant123
replies.text: this! and the idea that "everyone is beautiful". It's harmful and invalidating. The world tells us where we stand, we don't get to decide. Not everyone is beautiful. True confidence comes in accepting that we might NOT be hot or smart or whatever and we are still ok.

You don't have to be confident only about your beauty. You can be confident about who you are, what you do and that being pretty or ugly won't change any of that. But it takes a lot of time, pain and resilience to get to that point. If I'm debating with someone and, to diminish my argument, they say, "Who cares what you say, you're ugly," I'm like, "Sure, but what does that have anything to do with what we were debating? In case that's what we were doing.," or "what? are you 5?"¬†
It can't be subjected to your right to exist, speak and experience life. When they say something like that, they want to shame you and, therefore, silence you. Be proud of who you are and don't let them think for a second they can silence you.

I became confident when i started being told in my 20s that, unlike what id thought until then, I was attractive.

Oh and now in my late 40's being a 100 pounds heavier and having stopped caring about my physical appearance because of many reasons... I seem to lack confidence again. Weird how that works.   Certainly i dont have any confidence that i can attract anyone anymore, the idea just seems downright ridiculous, and im probably right too. 

I'm not done with this video yet but i don't know if it will address that part of the reason ageism exists is because as we age we all invariably become uglier or at least less pretty. Like not everyone will gain a 100 pounds like i did but all of us will experience sagging skin, wrinkles, thinning of the lips and either our hair graying or falling out. Time will catch up to all of us and while having had good features will certainly help you be less ugly in age, at some point past a certain age, we kinda all get ugly. Rich people can fight it to a degree with plastic surgery and such but idk anyone in the real world who's not ugly by the time they reach like 75.

replies.author: @Zvox
replies.text:
its good advice in the sense that its true, its bad advice in the sense that its vague and unhelpful. my own dating life is proof that the sentiment is true.

i'm extremely disabled and use a wheelchair, and therefore, i am extremely ugly in a broader societal context. all through high school, all of my friends were dating and banging each other like crazy, while i just had to sit there and be like "while y'all are giving each other STIs and scabies, i'm sitting here and nobody will even so much as go on a date with me" and it was EXTREMELY easy to blame my disability and the way it affects my appearance and the fact that i have to use a wheelchair. i had a lot of ridiculously beautiful friends, but even my less attractive friends were all dating and having sex. i got more and more down on myself, and over the course of years, began to wallow more and more deeply in self-pity and self-loathing and obsession about the ways i was ugly and undateable. i got some variation of "just be yourself" or "just be confident" for years, including from my femme friends that had previously turned me down, which only made it worse. its a good thing incel forums weren't around in the 00s, or i think i would have definitely fallen victim to incel ideology at that time.

then, one day, i made a new friend. a new friend that flirted back when i flirted with her. even just that was enough to make me feel so much better about myself, but eventually we slept together. when that happened, it caused this whole chain reaction of epiphanies about myself, the world, beauty and unattractiveness, all sorts of things. most importantly though, i realized that it was completely fucking pointless to even think about my disability at all in the context of dating and romance because its not like i can do fuckin ANYTHING about it at all, so what was the point? how was obsessing over my unattractiveness doing anything for me other than making me feel bad about myself? especially since i now had proof that, even with all the shit making me unattractive, there were STILL people that were interested in me enough to sleep with me. so, i made a VERY conscious decision to stop any and all negative self-talk. in my mind, i decided, "i'm awesome, and anybody that disagrees is wrong" and i told myself this all the time. any time i felt wronged or rejected by someone, i told myself, "that person is wrong, and why would i even want the approval or attention of someone that feels that way about me in the first place?". when i had some kind of intrusive thought about things i didn't like about my appearance, i would stop the thought in its tracks with a "eh, who cares, i'm still cool as fuck".

it was completely life changing. i surprisingly quickly started to genuinely feel good about myself pretty much all the time, and people started to actually want to date me. i had people approaching me to ask ME out, an ugly little broke weirdo in a wheelchair, which is unbelievably rare as a masc person that almost exclusively dates women without even factoring in the ugliness aspect of it all. through a huge chunk of my 20s, i was never single for more than a few months at a time, and on the occasions that i was single for longer than a few months, i was at least going on dates with new people fairly regularly.

being comfortable in your own skin and confidence about who you are as a person doesn't completely negate unattractiveness, but it certainly helps a LOT because attractiveness isn't just "how you look". i'm not exaggerating at all when i say that learning to have confidence in myself was completely life changing. so, it is TRUE that "just be confident" is good advice, it's not HELPFUL. the actually helpful advice is to stop talking negatively about yourself. focus on the aspects of yourself, both physical and non-physical, that you like. make that shit pop, exaggerate that shit. find new things that you like about yourself. literally lie to yourself if you have to, i did at first, and then eventually i wasn't lying to myself anymore. stop giving a shit about the opinions of people that don't like you, because they're completely irrelevant anyway.

"just be confident" isn't even remotely as simple as it sounds, but it IS correct. nobody wants to be around someone that hates themselves, romantically or otherwise. the hard part is learning HOW to love yourself, but it is the single best and most powerful thing you can do in your life. its a conscious decision that you have to make and then keep making every day until you die.

replies.text: Pretty privilege given to autistic people (girls especially) is a double edged sword. Yes, you aren't subject to the same discrimination are autistic people who are ugly or visibly disabled, but not getting a diagnosis or help because people assume you aren't like the ugly autistic stereotype is awful. Being a pretty autistic teenage girl sucked. Girls think you think you're better than them, when what you are is confused by the social codes. Boys think you're frigid and that you think you're too good for them, when they flirt and it goes over your head. I'm not exaggerating when I say I'm beautiful. People say I look like Audrey Hepburn. I won the genetic lottery on lookism and lost on ableism. I was undiagnosed into my 30s. I have had an objectively bad time because pretty privilege made my blatant autistic behaviour look like vanity. I just wanted friends, but I was deeply lonely. Attractive autistic people do get bullied for their behaviour, but our behaviour isn't recognised as autistic. You're beautiful, so everyone should like you, but nobody does, so you must have something fundamentally unlovable about you. It's a headfuck.

author: @sallysellsseashell
text:
My experience, that I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve really seen anyone else discuss, is that I was a very pretty child who became ugly during puberty. I very much was the capital P Pretty ideal as a kid; blonde, blue eyed, skinny. As a kid I was told that I was pretty a lot by adults and peers. It was part of my identity. When I went through puberty I gained weight in the wrong places and my nose got bigger in a way that changed my face symmetry. The change in how I was treated by both adults and peers was huge shock to me and honestly traumatic to deal with as a middle school age kid. I‚Äôm still fat and ugly and I‚Äôve never really let go of the idea that I‚Äôm actually ‚Äúsupposed‚Äù to be pretty, like it‚Äôs this right I had taken from me. I hate how much of my time and energy has been put into trying to get closer to the ideal standard and just how much self hatred I still have as a fully grown woman for my looks. 

I‚Äôve always known on a gut level that I‚Äôve been discriminated against for being ugly, and I‚Äôve been on the journey of reclaiming fatness and embracing body neutrality/fat liberation for about a decade, I‚Äôve never done this with my ugliness. Thank you for making this video, it‚Äôs given me a lot to think about, and I do think it‚Äôs a very important conversation to have.

replies.author: @nadinegriffin5252
replies.text:
I like watching older media.  I love seeing the unique beauty in people of all shapes and sizes, and with all sorts of different facial features.  

I actually suffer from crowd/face blindness.  I tend to brush people the wrong way because I can't recognize them from one encounter to another.  So I prefer interesting faces or features because I can recognize the person better and faster than someone who blends into the crowd.

I think as an individual, we can work towards changing our perception of people and then by extension, our social circles.  People tend to think they deserve attention and to be able to date someone they find more attractive than themselves.  Studies have shown this to not be the case.  So the only way to flip the script is to choose a partner lower (gasp) than the level that you think you are.

There are so many multi-facets to what makes an individual a person.  Lets stop judging people based on their looks, age,  clothing, social caste and just be friendly with everyone we encounter.  But we can't do that because then we might actually have to be friends with someone beneath where we deem ourselves to fit into society.  ü§ØüôÑ

So since, that is an impossibility, let's just stop condemning people for having choice on what they want to date or on what they find attractive and just learn to accept that maybe you weren't right for them.  If all goes well, it really doesn't matter how many people you find or that find you attractive as you really only need one partner in life to love you as you age and be by your side though the myriad of challenges you will face in life.

Quit being mad because you weren't someone's choice and just work at trying to find the one that does like you for you.  That person might be shorter, balder, fatter, than you thought or not.  The point is to move on and keep trying and quit being upset or mad that someone didn't choose you.  

So what if guys find Sydney attractive.  Guys find a lot of girls attractive.  And if a person wants to date outside of their race or not is their personal choice.  

If we just could quit judging and blaming and just work at treating eveyone how we would like to be treated, maybe the world would be a better place.   Look at how Jesus dined with tax collectors, and spoke to the women at the well... We all just need to focus on having more compassion and quit brushing people off and painting them all with the same brush.  

I didn't get all the way through your video.  I was listening to over half of it as I was tackling a painting project.  My husband came in and was listening and was asking why I was listening to your video.  He especially didn't like a section where you spoke about all white men thinking a certain way.  He didn't like being cast into such a generalized us vs. them mentality that he can only be one way because he is white and male. 


I kept listening for awhile longer but the longer I listened, the more I felt there was too much us vs. them and the bias and strawman arguments were just going around in a circle without providing a clear logical framework as to why your video was the length it was.

I appreciate the YouTube platform and I like to explore different points of view but I prefer clarity and consideration of the viewers time when it comes to the content creators that I will return to watch another video by.  I do have to say that I did appreciate that you didn't have background music.  I click off videos right away that talk with music in the background.

replies.author: @aikaterineillt9876
replies.text:
I was made to go to many a therapist (and the like) because I was responding (as anyone would) to mistreatment and discrimination over my general appearance, my immutable characteristics. I recall one of these "therapists"..young, same race as me, slender as I was..but she was pretty head-to-toe, and I was decidedly not (I was dehumanized for things above and below the neck). I walked in the room where she sat, took one look at her (as well as the aura of affluence that surrounded her) and walked right back out. She should have known..and I am sure she did in truth. She should have done the same thing I did after taking one look at me..acknowledge the disparity and walk away, but instead she tried to insist herself upon me, until I refused to visit that practice altogether. She was only proving what I already feared the more time she forced me to spend with her. I had to wonder if she got off on it.  
But individual therapists are not the only problem, it is the psychiatrization of vulnerable, disenfranchised people and trauma itself that is the overarching issue, the fact that society prefers to pathologize the response of the victim rather than persecute the role of others/society. The mental health system would rather label someone as inherently "ill" instead of what they really are..inevitably, irrevocably damaged and mentally distressed from their circumstances.

author: @Mae_forrest
text:
I am and always have been considered Ugly (structurally) and I remember when I was confronted with the blindness that pretty privilege incurs upon pretty people. I had just gotten out of a rough breakup, and my friends wanted to take me to a dance hall. I thought "what the hell" and went, despite not knowing how to dance, nor being confident anyone would want to dance with me. I was told, repeatedly, that my fears were unfounded, and if I asked anyone to dance that they would say yes. Friends, let me tell you how much that backfired. I had spent half an hour nursing a beer by myself, psyching myself up. I got up and went over to someone, and asked to dance with them. I was met with a stare that haunts me to this day. Not even a word. No verbal refusal necessary. That stare said to me, "how dare you ask me that question." How dare I step outside my loneliness. How dare I think I was on some level equal with someone Pretty. Message received. 
My friends, in horror, watched this happen to me. They never had this problem. they never had seen anyone have this problem, a problem I had faced all my life. They rushed to gather their cohort, and wrangled some dance partners for me for the night, but the damage was done. My soul was destroyed, in public, and not only that, I confronted my pretty friends with the reality that was my burden to bear. They never asked me to go out dancing with them again. I think it was as traumatic for them as it was for me. (thankfully, I was able to fall in love with my current partner, and never have to worry about being alone again, but that pain still aches.)

author: @shavocadooo
text: I've also often heard people talk about how traits in pretty people are deemed attractive, but are seen as flaws in ugly people, like how they can either be seen as "outgoing" or "talks too much." But one thing I don't hear people say as much is that this also applies to negative traits, like how people have much less patience and kindness when an ugly person is acting in a way that might not be the best, but isn't the most egregious thing ever. It creates a perfect victim narrative where it gives people the ability to say "I don't hate them because they're ugly but because of this problem they have," when really it's a combination of both that flaw AND the urge to punish them more for it because they're ugly, so they should try to be better everywhere else.

author: @gotjams5800
text:
Back in 2023, I went to a few anime conventions with a friend where we cosplayed different characters from JJK. We had pretty accurate cosplays and didn't differ much from one another in terms of props used, amount of makeup, skin cutouts, etc., but BOY was the difference in treatment from both men and other women notable. 

At one of the cons, this guy with a group of friends stopped us and gushed over my friend's cosplay, saying he loved JJK, her cosplay was so cool, and that he was really excited for the next arc of the anime and the next manga chapters. His friends noticed my cosplay (a character whose appearance drastically changed/had major character development in the manga and was going to be animated soon) and kept telling him, "hey, XYZ character is right there too!" but he didn't want to acknowledge me. Instead, he just handed me his phone silently and made me take their photo. When I mentioned how weird that was to my friend once they'd left, she agreed that it was odd but brushed it off as him just being excited. While this could've been the case, I feel like the guy could've at least said hello to both of us (there was no way he could've only spotted her because we were walking side by side + no way he didn't recognize my cosplay because he said he read past the point where it shows up) and asked me politely for the photo, regardless of whether I'm attractive to him or not. 

For another con, we went to a club after the con ended. There, my friend was surrounded by girls who'd tell her she was beautiful and gorgeous, and when they saw me next to her, they'd quickly say "oh, you're cute/pretty too, don't worry!" in this pitying, infantilizing tone that just made me feel bad. There was also another guy who shoved himself between me and her and handed her his phone to get her number. Though that was objectively creepy, the way he thought it was OK to push in between us (and mind you it was crowded so we were close together to begin with) and not even say "excuse me" to me so he could talk to my friend made me pretty annoyed and upset. 

I want to clarify that I'm not jealous (none of the guys or girls were my type) and have absolutely nothing against my friend here, but as someone who knows they're "ugly" by society's standards, I have this nagging feeling that these all wouldn't have happened/had a slimmer chance of occurring if I were considered attractive. I don't think I'm abhorrently ugly, but I know where I stand. I'm fairly confident in my abilities/accomplishments, but as others have commented, that cannot replace the sting I feel when others treat me badly because of how I look. Bullies are one thing to deal with, but I feel like friends who unintentionally downplay their "ugly" friends' concerns by telling them "you just need to get over that insecurity!" or "omg nooo you're so beautiful!" make the situation even worse, IMO. Perhaps this is inevitable, but the attempts to comfort just create a growing disconnect between what I'm being told by loved ones and what I receive from the greater public. I don't have a solution for what to say instead, but I just want to point out the way these things make me feel -- someone else may enjoy being told these things, and that's completely OK (and ngl probably healthier to take in stride lol). 

And of course, thank you so much for making this video, it made me feel seen.

replies.text:
interesting perspective, cause i have what i would consider strong trauma from growing up very unattractive, like i used to be so angry at all the years that were stolen from me, etc etc... but then i had my "glowup" in my 20s (which i refer to as a transition, i firmly believe some unattractive masculine cis women can suffer strong gender dysphoria and alleviate it with physical changes similar to trans women), and the point i'm trying to make is... after my transition, i literally completely forgot i was ever "ugly" and immediately became an extremely happy, confident little narcissist. so i don't think everyone has lifelong issues and everyone's just super different. then again i never really gave af about how others saw or treated me, i was just so unhappy with what *i* actually saw in the mirror and now i'm happy with it. 
btw i've actually seen a term going around for this called "cisgender trans woman", maybe that's how you or others felt as well, idk.

replies.author: @idab9958
replies.text: ‚Äã@stonersiren Maybe it's easier to get over that trauma if you don't care about how others see or treat you? I was never able to not care about that, because I was bullied, rejected and excluded and that was what was traumatic. If I had just been ugly and nobody cared or treated me badly because of it, I would probably feel differently.

replies.author: @idab9958
replies.text: ‚Äã@DizzyBusy Beauty is *both* a matter of opinion and a standard that is enforced by society. A person's individual, subjective opinion of what is beautiful to them and society's standard of beauty are different things, but they don't exist completely independently of each other. It would be naive to claim that the former is never influenced by the latter.

replies.author: @katiem2420
replies.text: Same except I never glowed up haha.

replies.author: @Vale-fd4pk
replies.text: I perfectly understand what you are talking about. When I was a teen I had a guy shouting at me that I was ugly as hell and boys in my high school used to grade the girl in the class and they gaved me a 6/10, I was never noticed even if I'm 1.80 cm and I started to close myself up and was convinced that I will never truly be accepted because I was ugly .... I turned 20 and my body changed like crazy (when people look at pictures of me in my teens they struggle to recognize me.... I don't know what happened) and people noticed, still there's always a voice in my head that tells me that people are disgusted by my appearance and can't get over it... it's crazy how much I like how I look, but it is not enough to get over this.

replies.author: @quinntrbl
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã Oh god has this been a struggle! I just recently turned 21 and my body has changed crazy fast. I'm the skinniest ive been at my height, and my body is way more feminine now, coming from a girl that always felt like she was built like a minivan. I've genuinely never felt pretty in my life, or if I did, it would fade so quickly. I had a very bad thought that has haunted me since the moment I thought it: I'm pretty enough to settle for but not pretty enough to be that first love you still think of forty years on. 

I still feel so ugly, I don't think I'll ever feel truly beautiful. I actually like how my body looks now but I still find my face a little unfortunate.

I always try to remind myself that I am beautiful, to be grateful towards my body for functioning without any issues. Like, I'm so lucky to have two working eyes. A working nose. A mouth I can use.

I also try to remind myself that people that only value beauty aren't people I want in my life to begin with. I don't want someone that only likes me for my looks because that will fade so quickly, and they will leave.

replies.author: @quinntrbl
replies.text:
‚Äã@idab9958I hate to go on but I can go on and on about this. My feelings towards beauty change so much because I always have contradicting thoughts. Like, I will think I'm the ugliest person alive... then I tell myself of course I'm not, and that it's self centered to think that way when people have literally been murdered over physical disabilities.

I have an ego I need to get over because I desperately want someone to look at me like I'm the most beautiful person in the world, and I don't like to feel like I am mid despite the fact that I am. I look so average. I should be okay with that, it shouldn't matter if I'm average. But I want to be special to someone. I want to be attractive to someone. I want to be acknowledged.

But I also don't! I don't like talking to people, I'm awkward. I dont like going out or travelling all that much. That's why I hate it, because my mind craves and rebukes it all in the same sentence. Cares both too much and not at all.

author: @Cherri_Stars
text: This video made me think of Catfish the TV Show. Ugliness frequently feels so conspicuously unacknowledged on that show. The catfish will be using the pictures of a hot person. And the "victim" will be like, "oh it's not about what they look like, we have a deep connection through our conversations." And then once they're revealed to be ugly, the "victim" will say, "I'm not interested in dating you anymore. It's not about what you look like. It's that you lied to me." And the "victim" and the hosts will encourage the person to just try and start dating as themselves, no more lying. Ummmm, we know damn well they wouldn't be making those same connections using their own photos. It feels so disingenuous!

replies.author: @anarchsnark
replies.text: Every. Episode. It was painful how predictable the responses were to the Catfisher's appearance. "We have a deep connection. I don't care what they look like" to "oh...you didn't tell me they'd be fat. Nevermind."

Even though those shows were completely staged, but do online daters not realize that beautiful people do not need to rely on shady dating sites for romance?

replies.author: @BadIdeaSociety
replies.text:
It is a difficult cultural expectation to unlearn. We have been taught for decades to value "inner beauty" and that it is rude to belittle the shortcomings of others, generally speaking. We are, on some level, socially expected to respond against people in our lives degrading themselves.

The other problem is that most of us have no experience or training dealing with this issue outside of the deny and affirm strategy. How do you respond when you are conversing with someone and they belittle their looks? The answer is not simple.

The final aspect of this issue that is going to complicate things further is that social media has given a lot of people a reliable outlet to seek constant positive affirmation. This reinforces the deny and affirm deflection strategy constantly. Not only are we not prepared to respond to self-deprecation with anything but positivity and gas lighting, but we are also equally prepared to massacre people who would respond to self-deprecation with, "Well, yeah, you are/do..."

author: @TomatenUndZwiebelSuppe
text: I like the idea of acknowledging that I am ugly and that's okay. I am a whole person with multi faceted experience. My ugliness should not stop me from going out anyway, engaging with my community anyway, and try to live comfortably in my one and only body anyway.

replies.author: @TomatenUndZwiebelSuppe
replies.text: ‚Äã@Nofurnohope your experiences and pain are valid! It is very disheartening to see how blatantly people discriminate based on look. But for me personally, I don't see our society changing anytime soon, so I focus my energy on strengthening my self-esteem in other aspects of my life. I like cats and cats like me back provided I have churu/cat treats on me at all time. So I dedicate time to spend around neighbourhood's cats. I like to crochet to fill the silence, or even plan ahead movies I'm going to watch on my free time. I've decided, since the world do not want me, I simply just have to make my own spaces and find my own meaning as detached as possible from my society which runs on lookism.

author: @struman5684
text: I bemoan to my friends that I am lonely because I am ugly. And they always, always tell me I'm not, despite my experiences telling me otherwise. I didn't have the words to express why that made me feel worse. Thank you.

replies.author: @suzanneoleander3224
replies.text: Just wanna add that ugliness doesn't mean one has to be lonely. It may take more work initially but having good friends and even a partner is VERY possible for us plain folks. The point of this video is more to highlight structural issues but that doesn't mean you cannot have close loving relationships.

replies.author: @aielianna
replies.text: ‚Å†@suzanneoleander3224 Plain and ugly are not the same thing. As we know beauty is a spectrum. You will not be treated significantly different for being plain unless you are in a space of beautiful people. If you have a facial disfigurement or have some combination of ‚Äúundesirable features‚Äù say a very large nose and crossed eyes‚Ä¶ you will struggle in every part of life. For some it *does* result in loneliness and/or being alone. Like Olay said we have to stop discounting people‚Äôs experiences. It is sad that being plain is also a privilege.

Unless the person you are in a relationship with is functionally blind as well as unincorporated into the social norms, you're still going to be eaten away at by your physical circumstances and the fact that even the people who claim to care about you still cannot see the real you without filtering it through your face/body that you had no say in and which you do not wish to be associated with against your will.

author: @pm0913
text: When I was like 11 or 12, I think, I remember crying to my mom about how I hated being bullied and made to be the butt of peoples jokes over something I can‚Äôt control. I was born disabled - cerebral palsy, I walk with a limp and have very stiff movement, since birth. She sat there and looked while I talked and didn‚Äôt say anything. But at one point, I was so distraught that I screamed ‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be ugly than to walk like this!‚Äù. Soon as I said that she bursts out into laughter and said ‚Äúokay girl you need to stfu now, you DEFINITELY just talking now. You know damn well you don‚Äôt want to be ugly.‚Äù She thought it was so funny that she went and told almost every adult she talked to for the next week what I said, like it was a funny story about the silly things kids say. And from what I saw they all said that walking with a limp was one thing; but wishing I was ugly was insane and I would NEVER want to be ugly. That memory is burned into the back of my brain.

replies.author: @Aflowerinthewind
replies.text:
@pm0913 wow. Just wow. I became disabled as an adult, and had a rude awakening then. But what really stood out to me is when not only was I in a wheelchair, but got really really ill, pale, emaciated, dark circles‚Ä¶ugly. When I was first in my chair people used to come up to me and ask what was wrong and pray over me and shit. It was wild, but what I didn‚Äôt realize was that was my pretty privilege. 

When I was at my sickest, people turned the other way. They‚Äôd try not to look at me. Once I got stuck in the rain with my wheelchair wheels, and just needed a boost up to the bus stop. I asked a guy for help and he looked at me, smirked, laughed and said ‚Äònah I‚Äôm good‚Äô. That had never happened to me in my life. I asked person after person and it was crazy how no one wanted to help me! I was offering all the cash in my purse! And this was just to go up the small incline to the bus top. Finally a young girl helped me, she was in high school, and she stayed with me till the bus came. I went home and cried. I felt so humiliated. And I was struck with the realization that I was now disabled AND ugly, and that my pretty privilege had helped me when I first became disabled and I didn‚Äôt even realize it. I felt horrified and disgusted. 

I‚Äôm still in a wheelchair, but I‚Äôm on the right meds (had an undiagnosed autoimmune condition on top of things), eating well, etc‚Ä¶.and I‚Äôm treated well again. It makes me want to puke. I am now stronger and better able to get around, but people ask me if I need help all the time!!!! People go out of their way to want to help me now. It‚Äôs insane. 

So, on the one hand, I‚Äôm shocked by what your mom said. On the other hand, I totally get her reaction. 

I can now honestly say I would rather not be ugly ever again. And I was ugly cause I was deathly ill. Once I got better and I didn‚Äôt look like a crypt keeper (see me saying that about myself?? Honestly I was just really sick!! Not my fault ‚Ä¶and ugliness never is anyone‚Äôs fault is it) then I was treated better. Still not as well as when I was able-bodied, but leaps and bounds better than when I was ugly. 

Your share just reminded me of that. It‚Äôs hard to put into words the feeling. Hope it makes sense. Thanks for sharing

replies.author: @MsDiane25
replies.text:
I sincerely understand how bad that feels. üíî
But pleased know that being "ugly" as a kid, or being called ugly by family doesn't mean that you have to be alone or even that you're destined to be ugly. Eva Longoria was tormented about being dark and ugly by her mom and sisters, and if you look them up you'll see it was a total Cinderella and her ugly step sisters situation. 
I was ugly. I started making an effort with my looks and getting control of my weight. The very next year I was suddenly desirable. I've been married for almost twenty years now to a man that worships me. And he has through all kinds of physical states. 
Please don't give up.
There are also people like me that find the most beauty in unique faces or faces with a unique feature.
Don't let not being beautiful hold you back. You deserve just as much happiness as someone that was born with a generally pleasing combination of facial features.

author: @kmaguire7161
text: As a gay guy who tends to be skinny-fat and with maybe slightly above average looks it was always such a weird feeling going back and forth between desirable and hideous just by gaining or losing 5-10 pounds. It made me hyper aware of how much my looks impacted my life. But even still I was totally caught off guard by what I witnessed when I had a very attractive Dutch friend come stay with me for a few months when I lived in LA. He was blonde, 6'4", broad shoulders, thin waist, model face and seeing how people fell over themselves to get his attention in public. At that point I had lived in LA for 3 years and knew no one and he was there for a week and already had a dozen friends. He would make friends with people he just randomly met at a coffee shop like it was nothing. It isn't that I wasn't aware of the difference between pretty privilege and the curse of being ugly or average. But this really drove home how different your life experience is on either end of the scale.

replies.author: @katherinebaker9909
replies.text:
YES! I wasn't the most pretty child, and my weight and skin conditions have ensured I am far from the beauty standards, even as I benefit from whiteness. I cannot emphasize how oddly comforting this video was. To have someone openly acknowledge what I was feeling but never allowed to express (because mentioning the way my Ugliness negatively affected me was always met with my thin, pretty friends telling me "oh no, you're  beautiful!") Is very healing and helps with some of the very internalized amounts of shame. 

I once nearly killed myself because of my Ugliness, and I have never known how to acknowledge that without it sounding stupid and vain, but my failure to meet the beauty standard lead to regular verbal abuse, denial of Healthcare, unequal treatment, and other negative outcomes that still heavily affect me to this day. I only recently got to the point that I will dress based on what makes me feel good rather than what best hides my Ugliness.

replies.author: @thankyouuniverse3682
replies.text: @RitaLifts yes, agreed. It's the value we place on it within ourselves that matters the most. Sure, I feel a little hurt when I go out and my sister gets all the attention, and still, I don't value being treated well because of my looks- I value being treated well because I'm a human being who has a kind heart and an interesting brain. So even when I do get positive attention for my looks, I feel myself put up an internal wall because my looks are always changing anyway and the way I look is not WHO I am, and that's not what I want to be valued for. I appreciate FEELING pretty, but even when I feel pretty, I know there are people who would disagree. So my experience of life is determined by me and my thought processes and the stories I tell myself, not what other people think of me.

author: @elenapapathanassiou2853
text: I'm not going to lie, I had to come back to this video because I was getting to into my feelings about my own experiences being ugly the first time, but I'm so glad I did. Your discussion of the structural issues faced by people who don't fit the beauty standard along with validating the personal experiences of how we move through the world (despite being a white cis person in my case) was really liberating, and I didn't know how much I needed to hear that.

author: @blobag
text: I've always known I was ugly in the sense that I deviate far enough from the cultural standard to not be attractive to a large majority of the population. I didn't have the same experiences that my peers had, getting asked to dances or even getting catcalled on the street. None of these things happened to me and, to the contrary, I had people blatantly call me ugly my whole life. Then having people tell me that I'm just being insecure when I call myself ugly feels like such a gaslighting moment.

yknow what? this video kind of called me out. i am pretty, i am aware i am pretty and benefit from pretty privilege on some level. ive gotten out of multiple speeding tickets (note i grew up in the south and i am a black woman), gotten into clubs for free, gotten more work in acting/modeling (and seeing modeling as an option at all at any point), and never been called ‚Äúpretty for a black girl.‚Äù just ‚Äúpretty‚Äù (again- grew up in the south.) i am aware of my privilege and yet felt reluctant to recognize people as ugly systemically when speaking on pretty privilege, and thus making any commentary i could make on it lacking. thank you for this. im gonna do better!

Then during the pandemic I shaved my head and gained a significant amount of weight and became invisible to people/ had a lot more rude encounters. Now I‚Äôve lost the weight again and grown my hair back out and suddenly people are a lot nicer to me and more forgiving of my atypical behaviors.

I'm always the ugly one in any group, and it weighs on you eventually.

author: @heathersmith8047
text: Thank you so much for making this video. It is an incredible in depth journey into a subject that is not talked about. I'm ugly. There is no place in this society where I'm considered attractive unless you include being considered "the exotic tattooed lady". But that comes with not getting asked out on a date. Only hookups. I'm not pretty enough to be taken out in public or introduced to friends or family. One man told me this:"Heather, I could never have you as my girlfriend because I can't take you around my friends or church friends". That is a direct quote. Thank you for addressing the gaslighting aspect. In person I'm never told I'm beautiful but online men try to tell me that (when I used to be online) I'm beautiful all the time. In fact the first time I was ever called beautiful was by a gorgeous man online. Long story short he was a romance scammer and I ended up filing for bankruptcy. Before I stopped engaging with the online community if a man gave me a compliment I would stop him & say: Stop. Don't lie to me. I look in the mirror everyday and I know what I look like. At this point being called pretty in any way is a traumatizing red flag and a clear sign of manipulation. Anyway, I really hope this gets picked up (unchanged) by a platform even bigger than YouTube. It is such a well done & honest film. I can't thank you enough for making it. ‚ù§Ô∏è

author: @Mezelenja
text:
As a African kid (üá∏üá≥) growing up in New York, people did not hesitate to tell me I was ugly. Whether that be my peers in my Quran classes or in public school. This led on even into High School where, unprompted, friends and strangers jumped to tell me I'm ugly. From "You mad black." to commenting on my lazy eye, or crooked smile. People were just generally rude and dismissive to me. I'm lucky enough that I grew up before that incel nonsense. But the idea of pretty people having advantages over ugly people definitely crossed my mind.

Now I'm 28 & definitely glowed up, (also I learned how to dress and groom myself) I get compliments pretty regularly, and they started around the time 'tall dark and african' started to be appreciated within modelling. People definitely treat me way better nowadays. I literally got invited to an art gallery because 2 artists stopped me on the street and wanted to take pictures of me. (ironically, they ended up not using the pics cause I didn't come out good) If I was ugly that encounter would just be a shower fantasy. I 100% notice the default respect a lot of people give me, compared to before I glowed up and I'm still the same awkward, dweebie and lanky mf I was before.

I could point at the world and be like "all of you are a bunch of stinky hypocrites" but I just don't really feel anyway about this. I do think the people who went out of their way to insult me are lame as fuck, but I'm also glad I'm not considered unattractive anymore, so I'm not really any better than them.

author: @starmax1o1
text: Well fuck. I'm only 40 mins in but this is how I found out I was ugly. I'm black, disabled, a little overweight since the pandemic and being diagnosed with auto immune issues... But honestly this explains a lot. I am autistic and demisexual and I think that factored in why I really thought it didn't matter that much... but reflecting on things... yeah this probably explains a lot of stuff from my life. I sell at craft fairs etc. and my husband does way better when I leave my own table of my own stuff T.T. Ugh, idk what to do with this knowledge now, I don't have the ENERGY to put into being pretty and id much rather spend my money on comics than make up, I don't even know how to do make up. All my friends are queer and autistic and never cared... you mention that being pretty has the benefit of 'better friends' is that really better? folks who care about that? it seems like it would be so fleeting. How do you trust a friendship like that? My family members get their hair done before they go inpatient for stuff and it always seemed crazy to me to worry about but... now I understand why no one visited me. Sick is one thing but sick and ugly... man I hate this.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: You do not need to do anything or change a thing! I know it‚Äôs long but Watch to the end, I‚Äôm going to get to why we should stop chasing beauty etc

replies.author: @aquaintsound
replies.text:
Body neutrality movement and learning about disability as a community identity helped me a lot - and just because people like us are considered systemically ugly doesn't mean that someone can't find us beautiful or love us. 

The biggest balm is self love AND it sounds like you have great friends who also aren't interested in spending a ton of time to try and match beauty standards. 

Sickness is often considered 'uglier' when it is chronic too (I'm chronically ill) because we don't fit into the Medical Model of Disability. Right now especially people want to pretend that covid and health are fully in their control so there is a painful avoidance. I have some chronically ill friends who are literally models who have had no or almost no visitors too. 

The biggest thing is not letting the way people treat you as 'ugly' make you hate yourself. In therapy i mourned my ugliness - not because i see myself as ugly but because I had to accept how that factors into how i am treated. Once you do that, then you can learn how to not carry that feeling with you. ‚ù§

replies.author: @starmax1o1
replies.text: @aquaintsound Thank you! I will look into body neutrality movement I have not heard of that one! I definitely still struggle with self hating my body but usually in the context of it not doing what I want it to do. I did hate myself (luckily have access to trauma therapy the last year that has helped a ton) but I also believed the gas lighting and believed it was something wrong within me that was just WRONG about me. I already feel lighter knowing that exists and is real even though I know I will be mad having flashbacks for the next week lookism explains perfectly. TBH I don't wanna be beautiful or even loved so much as I just wanna be seen as a fellow human... I swear being ugly sometimes gets that taken away. Covid was horrible but being able to socially acceptably hide my face, my ugly... I do miss that sometimes. It was nice. I still do often for myself but it comes with being a target now for other types of judgement.

replies.author: @starmax1o1
replies.text: @olurinatti Thanks I did finish it! Fantastic work as always! Thank you so much for making this video. I 'knew' I was ugly since I was a kid but I had gotten in trouble for expressing it and was gas lit so much I assumed that the events that I faced were some other failure of mine. I have wasted so much time ruminating trying to fix things, believing people who lied to me about this... (many of which turned out to not have my best interest in mind at all and this was a first sign that I wish I had realized).  I instead assumed there was some other way I was being wrong being deserving of such treatment.  All the 'how to make friends and influence people' self help books don't account for if you are ugly. This has awakened a new self awareness for me and I appreciate that truly! I used to joke that my dog had pretty privilege but I legit think that she has acted like a shield for my ugly curse when I take her to the farmers market etc. people are so kind. Cosplay as well has been such a lovely escape for me from all the isms including the ugly one. Dressing as a beast gets me treated more human lol. Thanks for spreading this awareness, its greatly needed. I hope we can all be more honest with each other and ourselves.

I was YouTube searching for videos "life as an ugly person" and your series came up. 21:47 in and I've already learned things.

author: @Sythmoria
text: I've had weight issues (20+kg overweight) and later lost the weight rapidly. I also got toned because I went to the gym regularly. The experiences are DRASTICALLY different. I just couldn't wrap my head around how drastic it is. This video touches on a lot of things I've experienced when I was overweight - never being picked, never being looked at, never being heard, feeling like I have to apologise for the weight I was carrying and just for existing. Being ugly is definitely a handicap in this society. It's soul crushing. And when I opened up to some people and shared my experiences, all I got was "no, that's silly, you're attractive" and we played this little game where all of us pretended we don't HAVE EYES xD as acknowledging my experience would cause a rip in time-space continuum. After losing the weight, I had a hard time figuring out how to respond to the attention and privilege. Also, the same people who looked at me with disgust before, later looked at me like a goddess, and it felt nasty and disingenuous and that messes you up even more especially after BEING ugly and EXPERIENCING the full weight of ugly experience

author: @phaIIicaIIyimpaired
text: I've been struggling with treatment resistant facial acne since I was 9 years old. It's like an automatic -10 charisma debuff right out the gate.

replies.author: @katiem2420
replies.text: I share your pain, and I'm sorry you've experienced that. My acne started at 8/9 as well and never stopped. The worst part was people telling me for years that it would get better when I left puberty, and then it just never did. I've felt perpetually unclean (even though I know that's not correct) for 25 years. And that's after 10 years of accutane... It makes it so hard to be seen and to accept touch from others.

replies.author: @phaIIicaIIyimpaired
replies.text:
‚Äã@katiem2420 solidarity ü´Ç‚ù§

I was on isotretinoine (aka Accutane) for 2 years myself and it was the only thing that even remotely made a difference, but I'm not willing to risk my liver by being so reliant on it for an overall lackluster result.

The most frustrating thing during puberty was people taunting me with things like "ever heard of (popular skin care product)" or questioning my hygiene in general. As if I wasn't trying absolutely everything. It's a deeply helpless demoralizing feeling, chipping away at your confidence. 

Most anti acne products I've tried only ever made it worse.

And yes, getting out of puberty but your skin never fully clearing up again feels like a giant betrayal.

replies.author: @SarahRenz59
replies.text: @katiem2420 Another terminal acne victim here. I'm post-menopause and I STILL break out, albeit much, much less than I did pre-menopause. And yes, the pimples, blackheads, huge pores, and scars have taken a toll on my appearance and have people treating me like garbage. What I really hate is how people believe acne is a personal failing, i.e. they think you're not washing your face correctly (or at all), you're eating the wrong foods, etc.
