replies.author: @ErebosGR
replies.text:
The only objective criterion of attractiveness is averageness.
What we refer to as "perfect" facial/body proportions are these averages.
The more we are exposed to diverse people and outliers, the broader those averages/beauty standards become.
This is why people of mixed race are often perceived as more attractive. It's the averaging of their parents' features that is perceived as attractiveness..
The most insidious and damaging misnomer has been labelling people with unique features as "average-looking", instead of celebrating their uniqueness.

replies.author: @judysm95
replies.text: @ErebosGRliterally screenshotted this comment. SO REAL.

replies.author: @RitaLifts
replies.text:
There is objective beauty and attractiveness - facial harmony, proportions of the face, facial thirds, facial features, bone structure, skin health. There are pleasant faces to look at and unpleasant faces to look at, and the more we are exposed to pleasant faces, the more we like them. I don't think we'll ever grow to like deformed or noticeably disproportionate faces. People like familiarity and conformity, not uniqueness. Let's not lie to ourselves. 

What society should rather focus on is taking away the taboo out of ugliness and treating ugly or below average (but not quite ugly) people with kindness and just as worthy. We as humans should be able to just exist as being mid or ugly, etc. without feeling lesser than. Our attractiveness shouldn't be the utmost value that brands us as individuals. To get to that point, we'd have to grow a lot spiritually. However, we're very far away, and are even regressing in that aspect.

replies.author: @7773CLA
replies.text:
‚Å†‚Äã‚Å†@BooksRebound No. There is complexity, relativity and wiggle room in beauty, attractiveness, social capital and desirability‚Äîbut the scientific ‚Äúobjective‚Äù study and understanding of beauty still exists, and Olay herself acknowledges it further along in the video.

Denying the reality of beauty misses the whole point of the video. Which isn‚Äôt to deny the notion of an ‚Äúobjective‚Äù standard of beauty, but that Ugly people shouldn‚Äôt be mistreated regardless of their unattractiveness.

Also, Qoves is legit a good, science-based and backed, non inflammatory channel that more often than not demonstrates the flexibility and variability of beauty. We don‚Äôt help the issue getting frustrated cus we don‚Äôt measure up to some ideas of beauty, but in voluntarily choosing to put stock in other merits, understanding and accepting that it won‚Äôt do away with age old notions of beauty.

replies.author: @7773CLA
replies.text:
She doesn‚Äôt, though. She explains the distinction of beauty and beauty capital, as well as the existence of a beauty economy and the kind of beauty that signifies and is ‚Äúworth‚Äù something within it. She explains the historical and sociopolitical reasons why some forms of beauty don‚Äôt ‚Äútrend‚Äù. But she also debunks the feel-good impulse to dismiss the notion of beauty as arbitrary‚Äîand acknowledges that beauty and attractiveness are more objective than most people would feel comfortable admitting. 

Again, there is complexity because like 70% of the worlds most attractive people aren‚Äôt a perfect ken and Barbie kind beautiful, and instead are some captivating combination of beauty AND charm, charisma, talent, intelligence, eloquence, etc etc etc.

replies.text: @RitaLifts Objective Beauty is completely constructed. We have been conditioned into what we believe is ‚Äúpleasant‚Äù and ‚Äúunpleasant‚Äù. It‚Äôs the biggest reason why attractiveness is partly constructed because you are influenced by broader society, what you personally find beautiful, what people of your race/ethic group finds beautiful, etc etc. At one point in time, even women such as Olay were considered ‚Äúunpleasant‚Äù to look at. Especially during the slave trade. Simply because of her Blackness. Another example is people of Asian descent were largely considered unpleasant to look at in Western society until very recently. I‚Äôm sure many Asian people can attest to this. Even capital B beauty will change based on where you are location the world.

author: @saldiamond
text: I'm only 20 min in, but I'm so glad you made this video. My confidence and self image goes up and down but when it's good, I think of myself as cute. But I know that society generally disagrees. I have tightly coiled kinky hair texture, I'm brown skinned, and naturally (when I'm not restricting food and not over exercising), I'm on the border of plus sized and I have curves in all the "wrong" places for sure. DeShaun's experience at clubs and bars was similar to mine when I was single. I wasn't attractive in my community or anywhere else. I arrived at a point where I just wanted to live life and not focus on romance. I got lucky and a fell in love with a friend who knew the struggle of lookism and we saw each other's beauty - we're now married. But if fate didn't work out the way it did, I might still be single. All of that to say: I understand pretty privilege isn't 100% fun but you sure do get further ahead in life when you don't have your looks repelling people or giving people reasons to treat you inhumanely.

author: @sixtyblackmystictraveler
text:
When I was in my mid twenties I got chicken pox. It was bad. All over my face, my body. When I was cleared to travel  back home I remember seeing the faces of people looking at my face covered in scaring that was still healing. It was what I had been running from as an anorexic bulimic over exercising obsessed with body image, my own and other bodies. I was in the fight ‚Äúto be attractive or not be unattractive‚Äù. For six months as the scarring healed I had to face my own fears around being unattractive, undesirable. It changed how I saw myself BUT it wasn‚Äôt a cure all. I continued for many more years being body obsessed ‚Äúto be attractive‚Äù. 
Thank you again for a great conversation.

author: @aquaintsound
text:
As someone who has been called ugly my whole life in part due to being visibly disabled, yes to all of this. I have trauma from people pretending they wanted to date me and then going psych! 

And it's no coincidence that ugliness is considered a monstrosity. Monstrosity is frequently used to equate how someone looks to their humanity- the more monstrous someone is, the less human or less moral they are considered. 

Disability studies goes into detail with how the christian church prior to the crusades told people that to be ugly was to be immoral and bad. Disabled people were kept on the brink of starvation and used as a bridge to help the white, non disabled church members as a path into heaven. Using pity as dehumanization. We have written documentation of this, it's horrific. 

So ugliness epecially includes a structural hatred of visible disabilities, certain ethnic features (distinct and non ambiguous although it varies over trend cycles), 
colorism and anti -Blackness, fatness, one's ability to fit into the gender binary, and even sex workers (often called ugly after a transaction is done). 

even expected measurements like chest, muscles, and butt are a factor. I've been told the only reason i deserve to live are my boobs or that it's a shame such boobs are on such an ugly person. And that's not uncommon, sadly.

replies.author: @aquaintsound
replies.text:
All that said, I no longer hate myself - i love myself. I don't cringe when i look in the mirror anymore. Shout-out body neutrality, disability justice and disability community, and finally having a non-white therapist. 

I accepted the way I am considered systemically ugly and mourned the want to be beautiful (which honestly is just a want to work less hard). Now I'm in full i don't care what people think mode - i choose how i show up. 

And i don't assume people are lying if they say they find me attractive - multiple things can be true at once. Confidence, voice, my transness, and even non conformity are hot!! Especially by people who are just like us

author: @EvaVerheij
text:
Your explanation around epistemic injustice hit close to home for me, I grew up fat (mainly due to a thyroid disorder that left my weight being something outside of my control), when I was 12 my aunt and mom had decided I should go to a fat camp, while there I was singled out by older girls and bullied. 

A 15 year old boy who was also at the camp sexually assaulted me (it was a relatively minor incident but it impacted me greatly), that evening I tried to open up to the girls who I was sharing a room with, I told them what happened and rather than comforting me or listening to what I had to say their first response was "Yeah right! you wish" and mocked me for something they assumed I must've made up.
I frequently felt alone around that age and that moment was just another moment that showed me that other people believed I deserved my suffering or that my suffering didn't matter.

That incident established in my young mind that if something bad happened to me I would not be believed, and I wish I could say that it was a singular incident but these things have happened at different times in my life over and over again. 
I'm not ugly, nor am I pretty, but I've always had to deal with weight struggles and as a teenager had bad acne, when people see you as ugly you are inherently dehumanized, you're not worthy of care, love, trust or consideration.
But I'm also white, blonde, blue-eyed, generally symmetrical facial features, fat girl 'pretty face' basically, and depending on what people I'm around they may perceive me as ugly or they may perceive me as pretty.. That was very hard to navigate when I was a teenager and young adult, I'm now 31 and it's finally become less relevant in my life as a marker of my value as a person but my experiences have made me incredibly aware of the privileges I and other people do or do not have.

Beauty is endless social climbing-rendered particularly arduous by the fact that, in our society, the terms that confer membership in the aristocracy of beauty keep changing. At the top of the hierarchy are "stars" who monopolize the right to launch a new insolent idea of beauty‚Äî which is then taken up and imitated by large numbers of people.‚Äù

author: @Sam_LB21
text:
I have my journal out and I'm taking notes. What is really hitting home for me is the distinction between being subjectively "pretty/ugly", based on how your looks are precived  by people in the room, versus being "Pretty/Ugly" based on the structural forces of society that impact material conditions.

It's this distinction that is never talked about. People refuse to acknowledge that being Ugly with a capital "U", does not mean you do not believe in your own beauty, all it means is that under a structure of beauty rooted in "white patriarchy capitalism" you are not the standard, and not being the standard has real material impacts on your life depending on how far away you are removed from the precived standard.

It's hard for people who are considered (p)retty to sit with the fact that they live in a lookist culture which they benefit from. And it's also a challenge for everyone else to accept that beauty is closely tied to "morality" and "respectabilty politics" in which people chose who is worthy of human dignity and who isn't.

author: @girlsthey
text: I'm only a small portion of the way through this video, but I want to thank you for this video. NOBODY talks about this in any real way, and it's so crazy-making! I'm white and I think my features are probably...average (?) by the conventional beauty standard, but I'm short and put on weight easily. When I was 18 I lost a lot of weight very suddenly and it genuinely SHOCKED me how people began treating me. I'd been a weird artsy girl who never had many friends or ever had a boyfriend/girlfriend, and suddenly there were dudes wanting to ask me out b/c I...looked pretty? It honestly creeped me out so much and I really didn't like it, but I was so happy to wear smaller sizes and have a body that looked "chic" in clothes. After college my lifestyle changed and I slowly gained weight, and the way I steadily became more and more invisible to people again shocked me. And people perceived me differently! While thin, I was "smart"; once fat, I was "intimidating." Suddenly I wondered if the (usually) thin attractive white women who befriended me did so b/c they wanted someone to make them look better, or b/c they actually liked me. It's honestly so depressing how it's constantly happening but no one will admit it, or if they do, they act like it's totally normal and appropriate.

author: @lycan4312
text: As a pre everything, non passing, trans man my relationship to beauty has been weird. the concept of discursive beauty is actually so eye opening to my experience. To literally everyone at school I'm seen as a extremely ugly chick cause of my shaved head, piercings, and goofy lisp causing me to be extremely insecure but once I found a friend group of queer people it was an insane shift to having almost all my friends say they had a crush on me at one point. Honestly it was kind of emotional whiplash going from being seen as horrendously ugly to having to deal with people crossing my boundaries + invading my personal space constantly

author: @sungseong
text: it's so interesting because I was always the Ugly friend growing up, thinking it was a personal moral failure, but then reclaimed Ugliness in my twenties. It was not so much to disparage, or even empower myself, but rather a deep recognition that being Ugly was a distinct structural social group like yall have articulated. Being Ugly is also so infused with being queer. Anyway, I love this video so much! I want to teach it to my students next semester <3

author: @justchilling7410
text:
Beautiful video Olayemi! This part really got me:

"People don't have trouble believing that an ugly person did something ugly. People assume ugly people are bad and beautiful people are good, because they want to believe that beautiful people are good. Because they value and want to keep them to be able to keep liking them in peace."

I immediately started thinking about how media constantly reinforces this too!

Think of the heroes and villains we've seen depicted throughout film and tv, especially in animation (where everything is drawn and made with intention)! The person we are meant to root for is usually pretty and/or good looking even if they are non-humans. And the villain / antagonist / person we are meant to hate or dislike is usually ugly or undesirable. So what does that say? 

And in some media it could be a commentary (or highlights the hypocrisy) like Wicked or The Hunchback of Notre Dame but let's be serious those are rare compared to the many. There are even tropes born out of this constant messaging such as the Disabled Villain Trope!

You‚Äôve said it before but white women perception on what‚Äôs big/fat really is different than what we see. (Ex: I‚Äôve never heard a black girl complain about a thigh gap)

author: @laminesylla1555
text:
Great work and thank you for this. I grew up in francophone Africa, relatively comfortable. There were many French white kids around me I was made to feel ‚Äòinferior‚Äô in pretty much all aspects, beauty included (cis male). I could never understand why I felt like this until way later when I read Franz Fanon. All love

More thoughts upon finishing, this thesis reminds of something I read about Beauty itself being a reactionary concept, which would help make sense of the growing obsession among young ppl with everything fitness/ gym culture/ bodybuilding/ looksmax whatever. Everyone obsessing over this makes the standard even to look 'average' increasingly high. 

Im also reminded of Yukio Mishima, body fascism, mma culture, the movie the iron claw etc...

author: @Not2IntoYou
text: Sometimes I think about how the people who are cruel to me for being fat likely would have preferred if I died skinny when I had cancer, the steroids I was given during chemo making me gain weight. And it gives me this strange boost of spite and will to live, be happy like "Man, fuck them. They don't know shit."

author: @ajschlesinger
text: I really appreciate Olay mentioning that although pretty privilege is heavily influenced by other intersections, it is its own specific category of oppression. I was in an online leftist queer group once where we were having this discourse, and at least half of them argued that there's no such thing ‚Äî pretty privilege to them was just an amalgamation of classism, colorism, patriarchy, and sizeism. But it's easy to imagine that between any two people of the exact same race, class, body type, and gender expression, the more conventionally attractive one is going to be treated better every time. I think that's pretty damning evidence that this issue is systemic.
